RT8hrxDADw9CYloryDUtFA.text: Organised a work function at Bounce a while back and have to say that their reservations team were great. They were available for questions and ensured everything was clear to me. I chose to pre-order drinks and food rather than a tab initially. They don't do any deals on food and drinks for corporate parties, which is a bit annoying seeing as we'll spending all this money, why not offer a discount or deal!!! Also meant it involved a lot of guess work as to how much food and drink to order for around 40 people. I probably overordered on the food and under on the drinks. Everything came out at once though, which I was not expecting and there wasn't nearly enough room for it all around the two tables we had reserved. Not only that but it meant that the hot pizzas then went cold quickly and food was lying around for a while. It is a good laugh and the food was delicious don't get me wrong, but improvements could be made considering the prices they charge.

Xz1QjTtRCwc8sXixp-PnVA.text: Such a fun place! We went as a group of around 12 for a work social and booked two tables for a doubles tournament. The atmosphere is lively with music playing and ping pong balls flying!Also had dinner there after and the staff were really helpful and patient with our large group. Food was tasty - particularly the pizzas.Perfect for work outings, birthdays, night out with friends etc

gX2nVRwacyUL3lX8SGARLw.text: We went to Bounce with some colleagues for a team night out - and reading the comments below, it seems that's a lot what this place is about.It's a surprising place in terms of atmosphere: big, lots of room, and full of ping pong tables.The food was okay, and spent most of the evening avoiding the ping pong balls. It was a fun experience, but probably wouldn't go there by myself.

3aWJr9MJNxiyeMBlGQt2TA.text: Probably one of my favourite places in London!Always great for a group night out or something a bit difference to the standard after work drinks. Love the fun and trendy atmosphere.Be warned - book your ping pong tables well in advance if you don't want to miss out!!!

lG_in0qDFYbRMJrMyq3Q5Q.text: Do you want to go on a date that won't be filled with awkward silences?Group of friends organizing a night out?Bored of going to the same bar or pub with your work colleagues?BOUNCE is for you! A fun filled night of ping pong awaits at this excellent central London bar and restaurant. Go for dinner or drinks and book yourself in at a table for 30 minutes or one hour (or maybe the whole night!). Staff are friendly and efficient and the space is bigger enough to book a large group for a special function or just turn up with a small group on the night. Warning: Not for the faint-hearted. You are highly likely to get hit by a table tennis ball at one point or another during the night

A2uDnOJTNdCkLs8Flv7j4Q.text: I went to Bounce as part of a team night out with my colleagues. We had a great time, but it wasn't cost-effective fun. It was different, we did have a really good time, but I don't think I'd go with friends as the drinks were a bit overpriced and it was £18 per hour for a table (bit steep). I was a bit baffled by the people who were there just to drink or eat and weren't with anyone playing ping pong. Surely there are better bars to hang out in where ping pong balls aren't flying at you from all angles :-p. I would only ever go back to play ping pong, and I don't know that I liked it enough to pay £18 an hour for it.

KYZ6I4vBzJsIU3usgTu7Qg.text: We went here as a large group and shared 2 tables swapping in and out of 'games', if you can call them that!! The atmosphere was great fun while you were at the tables although I wouldn't go there just for drinks as the balls do tend to fly all over the show and the drinks are very pricey! Overall I'd say ping pong then move on!

ctq8jZDEZIOPSNVE76z15A.text: The food is surprisingly great! I didn't expect much considering it's where Ping Pong was originally born! They have several ping pong tables that are reserved until the wee hours of the night in a regular basis. Best known for their pizzas, they also have a great selection of starters and other main dishes which you must try. Service always comes with a smile, and drinks are served cold. I recommend the local pale ale from Meantime! However, it can get a bit loud at times, and they often have a live DJ spinning tunes for the ones playing games...so, be prepared for that. I wouldn't come here expecting a quiet evening out. Otherwise, come here, and plan to have fun and enjoy the food, service and a game of ping pong where it originally started.

Eijf2tOF-BbE2suI6-6pdg.text: Bounce is in a very strange location.  You would never guess from its surroundings that several feet underground is a cavernous playground complete with flying ping pongs, pumping music, and a swarm of 20 something year olds.Came here on a Friday night and immediately noticed how packed it was.  Book your table early if you are coming here during peak hours.  It's about £13 an hour during peak hours,  £10 off peak.The cocktails here (about  £9) are decent: The Pink One was a egg white and raspberry concoction, and Winning Smash was like a lemonade whiskey and served in a short glass.

WAXVDMr7sIXFWggY2-sE2A.text: Great atmosphere. A really fun evening with friends. The only down side was the selection of food wasn't very appealing for people that like simple food. The curry pizza was recomended but i personally wouldn't recommend

y_0u0SHow2ylIAABniCl6g.text: Bounce is a good spot for what it is, the facilities are very well kept and equipment good. They have Coors Light on tap if that's your thing. Book a table ahead on a weekend. It's a bit awkward when they have to kick someone off a table when your time comes up, the folks we had to boot lingered a bit. One of the guys and gave me a bit of a look, but this review isn't about him.Pros: something different for a night outstaff are quite friendly and professional equipment is gooddrink/food prices reasonable although not cheap Cons:Ping pong is a bit expensive Booking a table can be a pain and you only get 30 min at a timeGets a bit loud as the night wears on

iB6hhZDiODfYJZz79Wic8g.text: Went here for a birthday evening out and was pleasantly surprised at how good it was. Good atmosphere and the food is actually very good. One of the best pizzas I've had in a while. Personally I feel it's better than ping but you can't play beer pong whereas you can at ping.

ctygMYFcj9OaJHg07rNrXA.text: Had my birthday here last night, and it's a really cool venue. Decent food and cocktails, but has a really fun and relaxed feel to it. They had a tournament everyone could join in with, and I really enjoyed the table tennis. Only issue is how hard it is to get a table to play!

2lmUAiavoJ_MHHMUgRVOAA.text: As a first time visitor I was majorly impressed. We went on a Sunday afternoon as a group of friends and it was the perfect activity. A really nice atmosphere and the food was great. I'd thoroughly recommend the vegetarian pizza, and the staff couldn't do enough to help us. We can safely say we weren't the best ping pong players in the room but with such an enjoyable venue, its a good excuse to return and improve our game!

Q0u9zPO4DcycWWRHJ_mR_Q.text: The ping-pong is legendary yet the food prices are a little too steep for the fare that fed me. £12.50 for a pretty standard, yet tasty, pizza smacked too much of location-pricing. The jolly atmosphere, frequent screams of victory/defeat and having to duck wayward flying ping-pong balls make for an energetic afternoon/night out!

j55rtMuyYoWuQutj-u5K3A.text: Good fun if playing ping pong although if just going for drinks, you get hit a fair bit so beware!! Quite pricey for drinks but worth the experience.

K23W21vcGJ7fklN6tCFvBQ.text: I went with a large party to Bounce on a Friday night. The place was rammed with people and we were lucky to get seats. The atmosphere and music were great. The place is crammed with full size ping pong tables with seating all around them. I like the feeling of mild peril you get knowing that at any moment a ping pong ball may fall into your overly priced drink or bonk you on the head.Although there is an attached restaurant, we ordered bar food to our table on the ping pong parlour floor. Portion sizes are tiny. We were disappointed by the pizza strips. There weren't many and they tasted pretty bland. Food platters were a rip off for the amount of food we got. We played a few games and left hungry.Cocktails were good and decently priced. I had A Shrubbery (Rum, port, lemon, sugar syrup, raspberry vinegar and soda) lovely. Many in the party had Tipping Points (basically everything from the drinks cupboard in a glass) and they loved them. Other drinks were extortionate. In my opinion £5 a pint is _very_ excessive (I am not a Londoner)I would recommend drinking and eating elsewhere and then going to Bounce for a bit of ping pong.If playing the ping pong hadn't been so fun this would definitely have been a 2 star review.

cXn5nu2OX1B-qgwolkNFBQ.text: I do love a bar that's different. I normally hate a sports bar. Which of these will win out?! Well the former (judging by my star rating) because the USP for this bar was pretty cool indeed. And if you're not a well-toned athlete (like me) it really doesn't matter because you can drink!Boune, aptly named as Holborn's foremost in ping-pong bars, was a short descent below High Holborn. I met up with some friends here to try it out. There was only 4 of us so we couldn't book on the website, which was quite confusing to navigate I have to say. But they keep tables free for on the night so we went to counter and luckily got a slot for 30 minutes around a table in an hour from when we arrived. Perfect time for a drink at the bar then! £13 for 30 minutes may sounds steep, but that £3.25 each so all in all I'm not complaining.This place seems really busy when you first enter and it's because the bar is next to the entrance. But push past those people that stand in throughfares drinking and you can easily find a booth or some space nearer the tables to sit whilst you wait. We split some white wine (£20 for house white is stupid because it wasn't that nice) and caught up until our time came to play. Thankfully I realised that 1) I remember hot to play ping pong, 2) that we were all of a similarly low standard and 3) running round a table for 30 minutes is knackering! Plus points, you can a bucket of balls (ooh err missus) and the staff are constantly picking up dropped balls to replenish you with, so you don't have to worry if you 'accidentally' smash the ball to the other side of the bar. Expect to get hit with someone's else's ball though, they do tend to fly around the place!All in all, a cool and different evening. I can see that companies bring people here for teambuilding type days, that's it's main market for sure

PRqqSI7nxiQFP24AcSDj5w.text: This is a unique place in Holborn (between Chancery Lane and St Paul's) where you can play table tennis all evening whilst munching on pizza! Nice atmosphere, nice pizza and nice ping pong tables :)

uboM7vTdFuAVm8eW4pP4Mg.text: Discreetly situated next to a Boots shop on Holborn circus, Bounce is a hidden getaway for the suits crowd searching for some after-hours fun outside of the standard pub session. Descending the staircase into the cavernous space below, one feels that one is entering a gentleman's sports club/smoking den, only updated to the hipsterdom of 21st-century London and decidedly unisex. Anointed by a blue plaque declaring the unlikely space the site where the game was invented and patented, Bounce is a veritable temple to that most frivolous of frivolities, ping pong.On a recent visit for our team's Christmas dinner, we were told to arrive at 17:00 sharp for the pong session, which we were only able to book for a half hour at the start of the evening. Bounce is run like a Chinese ping pong camp, with players designated half-hour slots strictly adhered to by the iPad-wielding staff who hone in on a team within seconds of the session expiration. Bounce subscribes to the Benthamian principle 'the greatest pong action for the greatest number', which is admirable if frustrating for a server at match point suddenly tapped on the shoulder by the red-clad staff. It is understandable, though, why they must be so strict in managing a pong-crazy crowd engaging in post-work therapy landing smashes and getting smashed. Everyone wants a turn, and on our visit, the place was rammed.Bounce does one thing and it does it well, offering well over a dozen tables with buckets of balls and 5-6 racquets per table. It has a freewheeling, loose atmosphere, with staff sweeping the floors between tables with pool nets for scattered balls, resembling Dick Van Dyke chimney sweeps grooving to the well-selected tunes. Everyone seemed in good spirits, even those situated at booths in between courts,  who were sitting ducks for errant strikes, gamely plucking the balls from their hair and tossing them back to the players. Generous space between tables also allowed for some butterfly floating and bee stinging, with smashes liberally sought and rarely landed by a boozy crowd.After our time at pong camp ended, we shuffled off to the side and ordered a drink while we waited for our dinner table. Bounce has a decent selection of lagers at to-be-expected prices. Unfortunately we did not sample their cocktails, but the fraternal atmosphere encouraged beer drinking anyhow.Thankfully Bounce's restaurant area is set above the chaos, which offered a nice respite from the gym-and-gin atmosphere below. Still, I would not recommend coming to Bounce for a nice dinner. The menu is comprised of unexciting Italian fare, catering to the Strada and Pizza Express crowd. Although we had to choose from a set Christmas menu, most if not all of the dishes appear on the standard menu. The dinner started well enough, with tasty starters accompanied by a glass of prosecco. The mains, however, were a bit of a mixed bag, and were served with subpar bottles of wine. The biggest disappointment proved to be the Eton mess, which was all mess, no Eton, having been served with no merengue at all.Still, at £44.50 a head, the dinner served its purpose on a work-sponsored event, where a modicum of meat is mandatory for avoiding  a drunken meltdown before the boss. The main qualm we had was with Bounce's service, which was wobblier than our own service game by the end of the night. The servers were downright confused by the size and complexity of our group, even with the set menu. They had mixed up the number of each dish requested, but instead of tackling each diner's request on an ad hoc basis, unleashed their harried servers on our group, circumnavigating the table multiple times trying to find a place to set down the misordered items, despite our protestations. It appears there may have been a mix-up with the ordering by email, but even so, the waitress should have redressed the issue by quickly taking stock of each order and sending out new tickets, rather than supplicating us to take the dishes at hand. Unfortunately the poor service extended to the ping pong camp counsellors as well, who short-changed us twice on the pong table bookings (shaving off 5 minutes each time) and rebuffed our entreaties with the gruffness of a gulag guard.On the whole, then, Bounce is a quirky venue suitable for large groups looking for a mid-week diversion outside of the Weatherspoons crawl. At £13 for a half-hour table's booking at peak time, I would not recommend it as an outing for the cash-strapped, which perhaps explains its shrewd City location. For a casual game with a few friends, I would recommend any number of good bars across the city with free ping pong tables, including the Book Club in Shoreditch and Doodle Bar in Battersea. Still, we all had an enjoyable evening and would happily be scooped up by Bounce's floor-sweeping staff to go back in the bucket for another round -- provided the company continues to pay for the privilege.

I0zRE2rlJqK9LA3UWDkVMg.text: Service is terrible, but its only week 3. Call them teething problems. Potential is immense, had a really fun time.

h2RfMPEbc-56x97w736Atw.text: Team celebration event at Bounce.  The event was perfect.  The game guru was an excellent touch for a group event.  Food came on time, drinks were ready when we arrived and it was an all around great time.

nUAYC1mzoscELBJ653obYA.text: We had a really good fun, playing ping pong and drinking at the same time. The ambience was very upbeat and would get even those who don't typically play get going. The staff were all friendly and efficient in getting us settled. Things could get messy quickly with balls flying everywhere, but they were also very good at picking up and refilling your balls for smooth playing. Drinks were good, although slightly overpriced for the quantity. I mainly drank the sharing cocktail, and a pitcher of it was £45.

pBbvRFEjTpvQoOw6ulD8ig.text: This place just amazes me - I had to stop a minute to take it all in when I arrived last Friday eve. I just loved the atmosphere (the gin probably helped with that) - the place is huge and heaving and everyone seems to be having a great time whether they're on a table or not.I have particular love for the DJ who I wanted to hi-five for the excellent old school tunes they were playing, and also whoever it is that flips the on the UV lights later in the eve. As if it wasn't tricky enough playing table tennis when you can see the ball! I have to say I actually surprised everyone (mostly myself) by being pretty good on my first go. My later performance at the table showed it was a bit of a fluke though!I didn't think much of the cocktail I ordered but switching to (strong!) G&Ts was a good decision. A couple of us also shared a goat's cheese and caramelised onion pizza later in the eve to line the stomach which was delicious - I'd eat goat's cheese off just about anything but I especially enjoyed this lovely light dough.Your only issue is going to be getting a table - make sure to book ahead to avoid disappointment, and I recommend a later slot in the evening than you think you'll need in order for everyone to get warmed up at the bar. Other than that, my tips would be to use the cloakroom (it's free, hurrah!), watch out for flying balls heading into your drink and avoid white underwear for when the UV lights come on. Enjoy!

photos.caption: Photo of Bounce Farringdon - London, United Kingdom. UV blackout ping pong! As if it wasn't hard enough when you could see the ball...

5gt_7EqYa_0kV84uMRwMAQ.text: Bounce is a great place to go with a group of friends/ colleagues or even on a date! Bounce offers you an opportunity to get on a sweat and forget about the week you've had. You can book the table for 1/2 hour slots at a time and bats and balls are provided with the rental of the table. But the best is yet to come...the staff come around every now and then to check you are well stocked up with alcohol. They take your debit/credit card, but don't worry, they keep it behind the bar and give you a token/key just so you don't run away without paying ;)Do try the restaurant if you go to Bounce. They offer a wide range of starters, sharers, mains and deserts for any number of people. From what I've seen its great for parties.Make sure you book well in advance as this place can get busy, very quickly!

photos.caption: Photo of Bounce Farringdon - London, United Kingdom. Red pepper houmous and garlic bread!

k7lHvOE6RcVn7oZTS-XeoQ.text: Excellent fun in a very large location. There are loads of tables here. Whether you'd like to eat, play or just watch, there is an activity for everyone. We were here for a corporate event which was structured by splitting us into two groups competing against each other. Whilst not entirely appealing to those who like table tennis it did help to balance enjoyment for those that were new to the game and others who had played more than a few games.Food was brought out and was pretty good. We had tapas style initially followed by pizza and the usual bar food. The great thing is that there are millions of balls so you never need to go far to hunt for one. Plus the staff have these excellent tools to simply scoop all the balls up into a net saving you and them the trouble!I did look at normal prices and it can get a bit pricey. If you're playing doubles that can bring the cost down quite a bit.In all I would recommend this place for the cool atmosphere and vibe, good food and fun staff, and most importantly it's proper ping pong on tables that aren't falling apart. The only real downside are the prices, but given the location and the crowd it's to be expected.

photos.caption: Photo of Bounce Farringdon - London, United Kingdom. Tables
Photo of Bounce Farringdon - London, United Kingdom. Snacks
Photo of Bounce Farringdon - London, United Kingdom. Bounce Entrance

oEBf5zh5Oo00MOS2EKQt5A.text: Just awful. If you enjoy either cocktails or ping pong go somewhere else. Clientele was unfriendly, uptight, and clique-ish. Staff was not much better (with exception of the bartender). If your idea of a perfect cocktail is a splash of ridiculously overpriced gin into a glass of soda this is the bar for you.If you like the idea of renting a ping pong table but hate the idea of getting sweaty or actually playing ping pong this is the ideal ping pong bar for you.

33DjKCIfckyK8hD1UasgvA.text: Super fun and trendy bar. Ping Pong the night away and enjoy a cocktail or two. Worth the trip and fun time to meet friends.

photos.caption: Photo of Bounce Farringdon - London, United Kingdom. Ping pong!!!

V8aER_P15FlrM-VAql7idg.text: Love the idea of having a bar with table tennis tables, as it makes for a more fun, interesting evening than your usual night out. However, it's a bit pricey and I didn't rate the cocktails - maybe I just chose badly, but found mine had quite an artificial taste. Food and wine were good though.Definitely need to book in advance as it gets packed, particularly at the weekend.

AjhReuqjqkV-jc1FjXQF2w.text: I am a big table tennis fan so absolutely loved my friend when she said she had a voucher for a free hour at Bounce.It was fantastic! It was table tennis but better as you didn't even have to chase after the balls! You're given a little bucket of balls and they're filled up by the people walking round scooping up all the stray ones. A word of warning though. An hour goes too fast in this place. Blink and your time is up as you're just having too much fun. I'd say four people is probably ideal for one table for an hour. Many more and you wouldn't get to play much. The reason this place lost a star from me is because I do think it's a little pricey and they didn't make it easy for us to use the voucher. They did let us eventually but it did take a bit of hassle.If there's an offer on here in the future I'd definitely be up for another visit. It's reignited my table tennis passion!

Q4c5qAYsxStXa7kcFH22Gg.text: When I think of ping pong (table tennis), I picture either college kids or start-up workers blowing off steam, or the furious combat of fast-twitch phenoms.   It's either silly or serious.Bounce pays homage to the serious game while surrounding it it with a club-like atmosphere and restaurant/bar.   In other words, it's a swank, ultra modern nightlife venue.  But with 14 ping pong tables and "art" that celebrates the game's history.And these aren't the crappy, particle board fold up tables kept in your parents garage and dented by the car.  These are professional-level quality, including one table used for Olympic competition.  Now is your chance to fulfill that dream of playing on the same table as Wang Hao or Ding Ning (and if you know who those people are, Bounce is your Wonka Factory).  You can go there and not play, or rent a table by the hour.  They plan on having leagues, tournaments and there are memberships available for serious aficionados.  The restaurant has a wood-fired pizza oven and serves other fare, and there's a separate bar if you just want drinks.  I also snuck my head into a private room that can be rented for parties, weddings other events that might be enhanced with balls and paddles.  Bravo to the owners for creating a palace for ping pong.  I'd highly recommend you bounce by as soon as possible.

photos.caption: Photo of Bounce Farringdon - London, United Kingdom. front
Photo of Bounce Farringdon - London, United Kingdom. stairs
Photo of Bounce Farringdon - London, United Kingdom. art

5_r0P2brSewfN9BGSmgMjQ.text: This place is awesome, probably explains why it was so rammed full of people!We were out celebrating my good pal RP's birthday and fortunately she had booked 2 tables for us to play on. Tears were almost shed at 11 when we were told our time slot was up, but the waterworks were prevented by copious amounts of gin and luminescent tonic!The UV lights got turned on at some point, and everyone went wild, I knew my drink was going to glow because of the last time I was around ping pong tables and lots of gin at the Yelp Elite Surprise White Party... so much gin! #Ginponganyway...Bounce is very cool, the drinks are strong and the staff are friendly, and the atmosphere encourages fun! And this comes from someone really terrible at table tennis!

h2N55igD3R4P_8Y8mseTHA.text: Bounce is exactly that - a lot of bouncing ball...EVERYWHERE!!Lots of table tennis tables and white balls flying everywhere. You can also book out sections for larger groups or corporate team nights out. It's a great fun place...though I wouldn't make it my regular. It's great for a crazy night with a good group of friends, as you could imagine, it's very loud!!! Though tons of fun. It is definitely not a place for a date or a business meeting. If you're a tourist, it's also a great place to meet others and socialise. Enjoy the bouncing action !

RR_cXQ3-ijiO-wV_xBXXGw.text: Yay for the atmosphere, level of fun and customer service, but nay for the prices. Great place to lose your breath trying to bat the ping pong ball every which way and the waitresses were lovely. Plus, Bounce entices you with the smell of food and prospect of pizza sharing its space with a restaurant section (which also happens to mask your lingering sweaty odours.) I'd definitely recommend it for a rainy day or any day really.My two tips would be:1) If you're counting the pennies, round up about four friends as opposed to two to bring the cost of hiring a table down.2) Get there EARLY as they're VERY punctual and you'll lose out on some precious ping pong time allotted to you.

i2qX--Sna7vv2rz0zikFAw.text: I came here with a few friends Tuesday night and had a great time! I think 13 pounds for a half hour is quite reasonable and the cocktail I had (The Pink One) was delicious. I also found the staff very friendly. This is a great place to catch up with friends and spend a fun, relaxed evening away from the pub scene.Tip: This place shuts at midnight on weekdays, so don't do what we did and make the mistake of not showing up until about 11:10! This is the kind of place you want to spend an evening in: you should have ample time to eat, drink, and play ping-pong.

8RDDn4azWoMkA0OoVTItoA.text: Bounce Is The New Rock and Roll - Not ! Having spent an hour in the car, curtesy of an extensive scenic route gifted to us by our cab driver, we were getting more than a little tetchy about getting to our destination. Pulling up outside a tiny doorway, still not knowing what we were going to be doing, we headed downstairs into Bounce.  By the time I hit the second flight of stairs, I knew I hated everything about it. A heaving, crowded,noisy sea of people, swirling around the bar, ping pong tables and mini tables covered with pitchers, cocktails and beers; all set against a pounding 'musical' bassline.In fact, that bassline was so loud and distorted, that you were forced to shout at even your closest buddy.We had a booked at the back of Bounce, on a raised stair platform, that faced onto the  restaurant which was just starting to get busy. Right about now, in one of my regular Yelp reviews,  I'd usually run you through the decor, food and drinks, but as I stayed precisely 30 minutes before leaving, so repelled was I by the people sardine/boom box effect, I don't have much else to say about the place.If you're a 20something who wants a great lively joint to hangout with friends or meet your buddies after work, then Bounce is just for you. If you're over 30 and want a chilled beer or three in fun surroundings, that allow you to hear what your buddies are sayng, then unless you like shouting, I'd give Bounce a miss.

photos.caption: Photo of Bounce Farringdon - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bounce Farringdon - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bounce Farringdon - London, United Kingdom

3WAPGVQ8I8Vz0b_qsVWruA.text: Ping pong and pizza!  (Thank goodness they don't serve Thai here!)I have to give these people credit as it's a cool and unique thing to do on a night out in London.  I only heard about Bounce because it was selected for a work outing and I have to admit I was a bit skeptical especially after reading some of the reviews on Yelp.We first had dinner in the restaurant which is to the back of the place.  We had the anti-pasti platter and it was pretty good.  Most of us ended up ordering pizza and it was surprisingly really good.  It's def better than pizza express.  Only downfall is that there isn't a huge selection so if you aren't a pizza fan, there isn't much more to go by.After dinner, we signed up for a table.  Luckily someone didn't show up so I think we had it for about 30 min or an hour?  I was absolutely rubbish but I have to admit it was fun trying.  I thought it was funny at first seeing the shower room but I can see how you can work up a sweat!  What else is cool is that they have one of the Olympic ping pong tables!  So if you're looking for something new to try out in London, check out Bounce.

qPqnlaUhXjQ5sS2WFwoGLA.text: Really great fun for table tennis. Fab craft beers and pizzas to die for! Best to book tables before hand to guarantee being able to get one. Enjoy

IV5i0h8X1Rlz2qUf4WiyZw.text: Ping Pong, also known as table tennis, is what you get here at Bounce. Play is supposed to be fast with quick reactions, but that's really only for the serious competitor. Here, it is mainly about fun. Tables are dotted around an open plan bar space. The bar is inspired by a Gin Palace with an emphasis on cocktails. There is an open counter pizza restaurant for something hearty, but also light bar and canape option to snack on while you play. Bounce is a great location for a date or group outing. Playing with balls has never been so much fun

AZ5s31ukyMLfXtjeDs2EHg.text: Great fun be u! I went there on a sat evening with a small group of friends for dinner and ping pong. We only played for 30 min but it felt just right about. The restaurant had a good selection of simple food and cocktail menu is quite extensive. Ping ping area has great du with very nice, easy going crowds...had an evening with great music, fund round of ping pong and fund conversations. Highly recommend it for slightly more active night out.

co8l72G3gBjN2q_KJ5ECRQ.text: Ping Pong, CheckGood beer, CheckAwesome pizzas and Flatbread, CheckLots and lots of ping pong balls? Check, check and checkThis is an awesome space in the often empty Holborn Circus area of London. It's entrance sandwiched between a Boots and the entrance to an office block (and behind a pillar) it can be easily missed. However, head downstairs and you find yourself in a large open room with lots of ping pong balls flying, a restaurant and a large bar. Book a table and it's yours, with your ping pong ball bucket helpfully refilled by various staff members running around with nets. I gather from those sitting at some of the tables (there are some amongst the the tables themselves) that the orientation of the ping pong tables could be improved, having the seats at the end of the tables meant that balls would quite often hit people when someone got a little over exuberant with their strokes... They serve Blue Moon on tap, which is one of my favourite US craft beers and the food is generally very good, we ordered various different pizzas and flatbread which all arrive very quickly and went down a treat!
